raw_text:
'Ultimate game' award for Doom 3
 
 Sci-fi shooter Doom 3 has blasted away the competition at a major games ceremony, the Golden Joystick awards.
 
 It was the only title to win twice, winning Ultimate Game of the year and best PC game at the awards, presented by Little Britain star Matt Lucas. The much-anticipated sci-fi horror Doom 3 shot straight to the top of the UK games charts on its release in August. Other winners included Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas which took the Most Wanted for Christmas prize. Only released last week, it was closely followed by Halo 2 and Half-Life 2, which are expected to be big hits when they are unleashed later this month.
 
 But they missed out on the prize for the Most Wanted game of 2005, which went to the Nintendo title, The Legend of Zelda. The original Doom, released in 1994, heralded a new era in computer games and introduced 3D graphics. It helped to establish the concept of the first-person shooter. Doom 3 was developed over four years and is thought to have cost around $15m (£8.3m). The top honour for the best online game of the year went to Battlefield Vietnam. The Chronicles of Riddick: Escape from Butcher Bay was handed the Unsung Hero Game of 2004. Its release was somewhat eclipsed by Doom 3, which was released on the same week. It was, however, very well received by gamers and was praised for its storyline which differed from the film released around the same time. Electronic Arts was named top publisher of the year, taking the crown from Nintendo which won in 2003. The annual awards are voted for by more than 200,000 readers of computer and video games magazines. Games awards like this have grown in importance. Over the last six years, the UK market for games grew by 100% and was worth a record £1,152m in 2003, according to a recent report by analysts Screen Digest.
llama3.2:1b: Doom 3 won Ultimate Game of the year and best PC game at the Golden Joystick awards.
It also won the Most Wanted prize in 2005 for Nintendo's The Legend of Zelda.
Doom 3 was released last week and shot straight to the top of UK games charts, followed by Halo 2 and Half-Life 2.

Electronic Arts was named top publisher of the year.

Other notable winners include Battlefield Vietnam (best online game) and The Chronicles of Riddick: Escape from Butcher Bay (Unsung Hero).
Electronic Arts was named top publisher.

The other top prizes are for The Legend of Zelda (2005) and Battlefield Vietnam (2004).
Electronic Arts won top publisher of the year.
The UK market for games grew by 100% in six years to £1,152m in 2003.

Developed over four years for around $15 million, Doom 3 topped UK game charts after its August release.
Other winners included Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas for Most Wanted for Christmas and Halo 2/Half-Life 2 as expected hits later this month.
The Legend of Zelda took Most Wanted prize.

Electronic Arts claimed top publisher honor, replacing Nintendo which won in 2003.
Over 200,000 gamers voted annually for these awards; UK games market grew by 100% over six years to £1.152 billion in 2003, according to analysts Screen Digest report.

The game was missed out on the prize for the Most Wanted game of 2005, which was handed to the Nintendo title, The Legend of Zelda.
The original Doom was released in 1994, setting a new era for computer games and introducing 3D graphics.
It established the concept of first-person shooter.
Doom 3 was developed over four years and is thought to have cost around $15m (£8.3m).
The top honour for Best Online Game of the year went to Battlefield Vietnam.
The Chronicles of Riddick: Escape from Butcher Bay was handed the Unsung Hero Game of 2004, which was released on the same week.
Electronic Arts was named top publisher of the year, taking the crown from Nintendo which won in 2003.
The annual awards are voted for by more than 200,000 readers of computer and video games magazines.
The growth and appreciation of games have shown to be crucial.
smollm:1.7b: The Golden Joystick award for Doom 3 was awarded to the game as it won both the Ultimate Game of the year and Best PC game at the awards ceremony.
The game was also nominated for the Most Wanted game of 2005, but did not win that title.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Doom 3 won the 'Ultimate Game' award at the Golden Joystick Awards, becoming the only sci-fi shooter game to win two consecutive awards: Best Year and Best PC Game.

Presented by Matt Lucas, the original Doom introduced a new era in gaming with 3D graphics and first-person shooters, while other entries like Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas and Halo 2 were notable as well.
The most anticipated game missed out on securing the 2005 Most Wanted prize for Nintendo's title, The Legend of Zelda, but electronic Arts captured Best Publisher by replacing Nintendo in 2003.
tinyllama:1.1b:
"Ultimate game" award for Doom 3

Sci-fi shooter Doom 3 has won the Ultimate Game of the Year award at the Golden Joystick awards, presented by Litttle Britain star Matt Lucas.

The much-anticipated title was closely followed by Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas, which took the Most Wanted for Christmas prize, and Half-Life 2, which is expected to be a big hit when it is released later this month.
However, it missed out on the award for the Most Wanted game of 2005, which went to The Legend of Zelda.
Doom 3 was developed over four years and cost $15m (£8.3m), and was thought to have set a new era in computer games with its introduction of 3D graphics.
It won the title of Unsung Hero Game of the Year, which went to Battlefield: Vieünnám.
The Chronicles of Riddick: Escapin from Butcher Bay was voted the Best Online game of the year.
Electronic Arts was named publisher of the year, beating out Nintendo for the crown.
The annual awards are voted for by more than 200,000 readers of computer and video games magazine titles.
Over the last six years, the UK market for games grew by 100%, with a record £1,152m worth in 2003, according to Screen Digest's report.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In addition to being crowned the Ultimate Game of the Year and best PC game with the Doom 3 title, Electronic Arts also received top publisher of the year at the Golden Joystick Awards held in London on December 15th.
This prestigious recognition is a testament to their successful portfolio of games that have resonated with players worldwide.
The winners in other categories were: Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas (Most Wanted), Halo 2 (Best Unreleased Game) and Half-Life 2 (Most Wanted Big Hitters).
The most recent installment of the popular Doom series, Doom 3, has been praised for its innovative storyline that diverges from the film adaptation released earlier this year.
This title was also recognized as the top publisher, earning EA the accolade once again.
Overall, these awards reflect Electronic Arts' continued success in producing engaging and immersive game experiences for players across multiple platforms.

It is praised as an important game that helped establish first-person shooter genre with its release in 2004.
Other winners include Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas, Halo 2, Half-Life 2, The Legend of Zelda, Battlefield Vietnam, and Chronicles of Riddick: Escape from Butcher Bay.
Electronic Arts was named the top publisher of the year, as the UK games market grew by 100% to a record £1,152m in 2003.

Other winners included Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas, which took the Most Wanted for Christmas prize.
Only recently released, it was closely followed by Halo 2 and Half-Life 2, which are expected to be big hits when they are unleashed later this month.
However, they missed out on the prize for the Most Wanted game of 2005, which went to The Legend of Zelda.
The original Doom, released in 1994, helped to establish the concept of the first-person shooter and was instrumental in the development of modern shooters.
